fields.description:
When I receive {{new version available}} notification, then download attempt fails. 

Also the download button on http://www.sourcetreeapp.com/ redirects to http://downloads.atlassian.com/software/sourcetree/SourceTree_2.0.3.dmg url, which shows {{Backend not available}} words.

Please fix.
fields.summary: Unable to download new version

fields.summary: SourceTree on OS X crashed on every check out of a new branch

fields.description:
I'm resolving merge conflicts and want to jump to one of the parent commits in the log.

I can open up the log view and can scroll down to find the parents (see first image), but this can be time-consuming.  It would be nice to have direct links like the ones available on actual commits (see second image).
fields.summary: When resolving merge conflicts, link to the parent commits in the log view

fields.description:
Even with the "compact" layout, the new Bookmarks window has an unacceptably wide minimum width that forces me to make all my repo windows narrower.

In 1.x, my Bookmarks window is exactly 320px wide, leaving lots of horizontal space for repo windows to be open next to it. The new Bookmarks window has a ridiculous minimum width of 480px. I have about 30 repos, and in every single case, there's well over 200px of empty space between the name of the repo and the badges/tags on the right.

Clearly the problem is the toolbar. The worst issue there is the "+ New Repository" button, which not only wastes a ton of space, but doesn't even make sense. That button does NOT create a new repository. It opens a menu of things you can create. Therefore the button should obviously just be labelled "+", which would reclaim over 100px of wasted space. You can then reduce the minimum width of the search box, and then the window should easily fit in 320px.

For me this is a blocker — I'm not making my repo windows narrower to accomodate a badly designed Bookmarks window — so I'll be sticking with 1.9.8 until this is fixed. Marking this as a bug because this was never a problem until you guys "fixed" something that wasn't broken.

That brings me to a larger concern: Would you guys please hire a real UI/UX designer before you redesign any other UI elements? There have been some major missteps in SourceTree over the past year or so, and the people who actually use the product don't find out until it's dumped on us in a new version. I'm now making backup copies of my current version before every new update in case I need to roll back (because it's very difficult to find previous versions), and that's a pretty bad sign.
fields.summary: Bookmarks window is still too wide

fields.description: Trying to register with a new domain ending such as {{*.technology}} results in SourceTree saying that the e-mail address is not valid.
fields.summary: Cannot Register With Certain Email Addresses Containing New Domains

fields.description: Tried to search for all files ending with tga extension using "*.tga" so I don't get any *.tga.meta files in the results, but the result set was empty.
fields.summary: Wildcards in search filter do not work

fields.description:
I set the filters to ignore *.tga from Preferences->Diff->Internal Diff and also set to maximum size of binary to be 1k, but still it it shows the preview if the file is not being tracked. If the file is being tracked, the filters kick in correctly.

This bug brings the client to a hault when selecting several untracked images
fields.summary: Untracked binary preview ignores filters

fields.description: there are about 20-30 remote branches
fields.summary: SourceTree crash when clicking on remote branches

fields.description:
Reproduction:
* Create a branch
* In a submodule commit some changes
* Commit the submodule commit ref change in the parent repo
* Merge the branch into another branch
* (x) The merge commit contains the correct submodule commit ref, but the submodule is currently set to the old commit ref, and is listed in the working copy changes

TL;DR: When merging a branch with submodule changes, we always have to reset the submodule afterwards.
fields.summary: After Merge Submodules are not set to the correct Commit

fields.description:
Using the {{Commit Selected}} menu item causes the focus of the cursor to go to the {{Search}} bar rather than the commit message.

Steps to reproduce:
# Stage some files.
# Right-click and select {{Commit Selected}}

Using the "Commit" button in the toolbar exhibits the correct behaviour of setting the focus to the commit message.
fields.summary: Wrong Focus After Using "Commit Selected"

fields.summary: Sourcetree 2.0.2 Mac crashes intermittently

fields.description:
Since updating to the latest version, the Stage hunk button consistently returns the following error:

{quote}
*Error encountered*

'git apply' failed with code 1:'error: patch failed: index.html:113
error: index.html: patch does not apply
'
{quote}
fields.summary: Error encountered when clicking Stage hunk button

fields.description:
Hold down the command key while clicking on two commits with several files that differ. One of those "commits" must be the working copy.

The list of affected files is generated, along with the text "Displaying all changes between XXXX and working copy." However, upon choosing any file in the list, the diffs do not update; only the last file's differences are ever shown.

Note how, in the attached screen shot, even though "amherst_preview.js" is selected, the differences for style-common.css are still being shown in the right hand pane.

If the differences are generated for two actual commits (not the working copy), the feature works as expected.
fields.summary: Can only view one file's diffs in multi-commit diff with working copy

fields.description: In the Git settings you can choose how to push branches (German: "Pushe Zweige"). Unfortunately, when user makes a selection, the localized value ( e.g. "nichts") is inserted into the user's . gitconfig file (correct: e.g. "nothing") which leads to a fatal error, when opening any repository window. When this has happened SourceTree keeps presenting alert boxes and can not be worked with anymore. You can't fix this error state from within SourceTree, you have to manually edit .gitconfig
fields.summary: Git settings fills in localized value for [push] into .gitconfig

fields.description:
Hi, this looks like a very minor oversight.

We use git with a very little amount of people and each of us has it's own components, conflicts are very rare. But we use branches a lot (git-flow) so that each of us can work on his features, not break the source base for anyone until the feature is done. Merge/Pull-Conflicts are very rare.

While explaining git/SourceTree(Mac)/our work flow to a new co-worker, I noticed this little inconsistency: Both the dialogs for PULL and MERGE have the checkbox "Commit merged changed immediately" and "Commit merged changed immediately (if no conflict)". (Obviously, both would only work if there was no conflict, but that is not the point).

The inconsistency is, that the MERGE operation only gets commited automatically if the according checkbox in the PULL dialog is set.
fields.summary: Merge operation reads "commit immediately" checkbox flag from pull dialog (instead of from merge dialog)
Overlapping text near header when in full screen

fields.description:
SourceTree crashes multiple times a day, mostly when changing local branches or checking out remote branches.

This is not directly reproducible but happens very often (The two crash logs I have attached are 20 minutes apart)
fields.summary: SourceTree crashes often on branch change

fields.description:
Hi!

I think it would be much more convenient to be able to drag files out from the panel of SourceTree.

I know I could right click on the file and choose "Reveal in Finder', but it's more intuitive to directly drag it out

Thank you for your hard work!

I love SourceTree pretty much! :D
fields.summary: Drag & Drop File Out From SourceTree Panel

fields.description:
Since 2.0, SourceTree crashes a lot. This is very sad.
I have noticed it crashes most when a submodule window is opened.
fields.summary: Crash when Submodule is Open

fields.description:
When I double-click on a changed file the file is opened instead of the external diff is opened. This behaviour does not add to my workflow of screening the diffs just before committing.

Please adjust the default behaviour of double-click to external diff if an external diff tool is configured, or at least allow me choose the behaviour of the double click (open vs. diff).

I found a related issue for sourceTree-Win: SRCTREEWIN-1469
fields.summary: Double-click on changed file should open external diff

fields.description:
Steps to reproduce:

# Select 'log' view
# Have 'All branches', 'Show Remote Branches' and 'Ancestor Order' selected
# Have a branch tracking a remote branch
# Delete the remote branch
# Switch 'All branches' to 'Current branch'

SourceTree displays the error:

{noformat}
Error encountered
'git log' failed with code 128:'fatal: bad revision 'origin/the-remote-branch'
'
{noformat}
fields.summary: Error encountered when remote branch no longer exists
Submodules' Change Source URL doesn't keep formatting

fields.description:
It would be great if the destination branch defaulted to the branch from which the source branch was branched from.  For example, if I crated branch bugfix/123-mybug off of release/1.0.0.0, when I create a pull request for the changes I made in bugfix/123-mybug I would like the destination branch to default to release/1.0.0.0.

Currently, when I select "Create Pull Request..." from SourceTree, the source branch is properly set to bugfix/123-mybug but the destination branch is set to master instead of release/1.0.0.0.
fields.summary: Pull request default destination branch is not set correctly

fields.description:
If a remote URL doesn't have a username specified it causes continual auth prompts because the keychain can't readily identify a matching entry due to lack of context (domain-only URLs don't provide enough information).

Provide some assistance to the user with some dialog linked to a help article on Confluence.
fields.summary: Auth failures on usernameless URLs should prompt user with help

fields.description:
I'm trying to clone a project from Mercurial repository over VPN connection. When cloning is about to finish (based on progress bar animation) SourceTree crashes. I can reproduce this crash every time.

Crash log attached.
fields.summary: Crash 'NSInvalidArgumentException' when cloning Mercurial project over VPN connection

fields.description: Long branch names (90 characters for example) can overflow onto the Cancel and Commit buttons and make them unclickable. It also looks bad.
fields.summary: long branch name bleeds over buttons in the commit window

fields.description:
Checking the box on an "Unstaged file" used to stage the file.  

Now, it just re-order file to the bottom of the "Unstaged files".

fields.description: When viewing a branch history in fullscreen mode, the sorting bar at the top gets messed up (see attachment). When changing to fullscreen mode it does not always mess up but then when you switch to working copy and back to branch history it is messed up. Closing fullscreen mode resolves the view again.
fields.summary: Sort bar messed up in fullscreen mode

fields.description: I keep all my repos, personal and professional in one workspace/directory. Since they're all in the same directory I cannot determine which account the repo belongs to. If I could get the account name from which the repo belongs, that would be awesome.
fields.summary: add $ACCOUNT to custom actions parameter options

fields.description:
SourceTree hangs for several minutes when staging files, even if it's not a large amount of files (even a few). The repository itself is quite large, but the number of staged files is low.

Attached are some traces from Activity Monitor.
fields.summary: SourceTree Hangs for Several Minutes When Staging Files

fields.description:
SourceTree hangs periodically. It almost always happens in the middle of a code review (lots of diffing).

Attached is a trace from when this occurred.
fields.summary: SourceTree Hangs

When editing the URL for a remote on the repository, the dialog box does not close when selecting OK, so the settings are not saved.

# Open a repository

fields.description:
When using the {{Check default remotes for updates every X minutes}} option, when a refresh happens, the current UI gets reset, even though a user may be looking through a file list, or file diff. 

The UI should remain the same after a refresh, especially if there is no actual changes on the remotes.
fields.summary: Retain UI State When Refreshing Remotes

fields.description:
Currently choosing "ignore..." on a file gives the option to ignore all files with that exact file name, the same extension or all files with a common arbitrary parent.
I would like to have the option to ignore exactly and only the selected file.
E.g. add "/relative_path_to_git_root/file_to_ignore" instead of "file_to_ignore" to .gitignore.
fields.summary: Ignore file with exact file path

fields.description:
Prior to 2.0, the repository browser used to show a the number of changed files, and the number of unknown files. This is now only shown as 1 number, which is not enough information. Please add back both numbers in the display.

The workaround is to press {{Spacebar}} when selecting a repository to get more information.
fields.summary: "File Changes" in Repository Browser

fields.description:
Currently the bookmarks view shows icons when known for bitbucket repo's or looks for potential icons as a file named `icon`. A web-project is likely to contain a file named `favicon` already.
To make the bookmarks view work with a little more 'magic' it would be beneficial to have it check for a file named favicon.* as well.
fields.summary: Add favicon.* to list of potential icons for bookmarks

fields.description:
If the file name contains at least one of the symbols of the Russian alphabet (Only those characters: Ё, ё, Й, й), the files are shown as Not Tracked.
Enclose a folder with files to test (text.zip).
All files test folder added to the repository.
fields.summary: Status of files Not Tracked

fields.description: Cherry-picking on command line does not update the SourceTree UI. (Note: This was all in the 'Log' tab, that shows branches on the left and commits on the right.) It took restarting SourceTree for it to show correctly. SourceTree already showed I was on the current branch, I cherry-picked one commit from another branch to the current one (note: the branch I cherry-picked from was the result of merging the current branch with another one, and then adding more commits, where the cherry-picked commit was one of the added-on commits), and when I went back to SourceTree, it didn't update. Clicking on the branch in the left side view list of branches showed a spinner in the commits view, and after about 15-20 seconds, it stopped, and nothing updated. I clicked another branch and it correctly selected it and went to its last commit in the commits view. When I tried clicking the current branch again, it had the same issue as the last time, so I quit at this point, and upon restarting, it showed the UI correctly.
fields.summary: Cherry-picking on command line not updating SourceTree UI

fields.description:
It would be great to be able to show the size of each commit in the commit list (and be able to sort on it). Also the size of the change per file could be shown in the commit details.

This can help to identify large commits. Repositories tend to become very large over time, because people check-in large files. It's very hard to identify which commit and which files are responsible for it. Showing the commit sizes would help a lot.
fields.summary: Show size of commits

fields.description:
Open a Git log window in full screen mode.
Open repository browser with ⌘B
Open other Git repository

The log window goes full-screen immediately, and is entitled 'Git Repository' in mission control (mouseover space thumbnail to show window title). If you open a window in a normal space and then put it full screen, its name in mission control is the repository name.
fields.summary: Window name set incorrectly when opening from fullscreen

fields.description:
When you switch contexts, the dropdown for the selection of branches to show resets to a default. It would be nice if the dropdown would maintain it's state.

1. select a branch
2. note the dropdown- it default to "All Branches"
3. change the dropdown to show the current branch
4. select a new branch

Reality. The dropdown resets to default "All Branches"
Expected: The drop down is set user's first choice- the current_branch.
fields.summary: Respect users's preference for the selection of branches to show

fields.description: I often name branches with a number that corresponds to a github issue and the sorting of branches is done in a naive way. The screenshot should illustrate the problem.
fields.summary: Sort branches by name, correctly

fields.description:
Hi,

First off, I am a big fan of Sourcetree, so thanks for that...

But I think I came accross a bug, when deciding that naming hotfix-branches as our internal ticket numbers would be more clear, while keeping the tags as version numbers
Use case:
 - I create a hotfix with the name Hotfix/ticket-9
 - I commit some stuff
 - I try finishing the hotfix and in the popup, I can fill in what tag should be used on the master after finishing. 
 - So i fill in 12.8 (for example)
 - But when I check my tags, I see that sourcetree decided to use the branch-name instead of the defined tag.

So, don't show the option for filling in a tag on finishing a hotfix. Or tag the master with the tag filled in the pop-up
fields.summary: Hotfix naming causes wrong tag

fields.description:
If there are so many merge errors such that the "Errors During Merge" dialog height > Screen height, then the OK  button disappears and there is no way to exit the "Errors During Merge" dialog.

Need to have a scrollable view of the errors so that OK button is always visible
fields.summary: Need Scrollable View for "Errors During Merge" dialog

fields.description:
SourceTree ignores the umask setting whenever it touches files in a git repo, which is counter to the way the actual git tool works. When cli git checks out a new file, or a checkout changes an existing file, those files' permissions are set according to the current umask value. But when SourceTree alters a file, the permissions are always set to 644, no matter what the umask value is. And yes, I've set the umask value for user applications, as specified in [these instructions from Apple|http://support.apple.com/kb/ht2202]. This has no effect.

This is extremely disruptive to a project being worked on by multiple users on the same machine. My system's umask is 002, because I want group write permission on all my files. But every time anyone uses SourceTree, that group write flag is removed from the files in our repo.
fields.summary: SourceTree ignores umask, changes all touched files' permissions to 644

fields.description: I just got this crash while working with hunks. I think I was discarding hunks by selecting lines. I haven't reproduced yet.
fields.summary: Crash while working with hunks

fields.description:
If you are using SourceTree in a language other than English, the changes made to the configuration in Git get passed in the selected language, rather than English, causing git errors to be thrown.

I was able to reproduce this for the {{Push branches}} setting in both Spanish and Dutch.
fields.summary: Translations Get Passed To Git Configuration

fields.description:
Whenever I scroll (horizontally) the diff box SourceTree crashes.

*Steps to reproduce:*
1. Use a "large" uncommitted change with many changes and hunks.
2. Scroll one large hunk (horizontally) quickly back and forth by clicking on the scrollbar and dragging it.

*Result:*
SourceTree stops responding.

Using SourceTreee standalone app 2.0.2 but bug from 2.0.0 I think.

Mac OsX Mavericks 10.9.5 (Mac Book Pro Retina)

JDK version: 
{code}
	<key>BuildVersion</key>
	<string>1</string>
	<key>CFBundleShortVersionString</key>
	<string>14.9.0</string>
	<key>CFBundleVersion</key>
	<string>14.9.0</string>
	<key>ProjectName</key>
	<string>JavaJDK16</string>
	<key>SourceVersion</key>
	<string>462000000000000</string>
{code}
fields.summary: Scrolling diff horisontally using scrollbar hangs
Support Git shallow clone & Git clone only one branch

fields.description:
Selecting Fetch with all three checkboxes selected doesn't remove origins that are no longer available on the server (Stash in our case.)

If there is another way to this I cannot find it.
fields.summary: Deleted remote origins not removed when Fetch with all three checkboxes ticked

fields.description:
Hi,

in the latest version, no icon indicates the current and active branch. I have two branches checked out on my machine. The active branch is marked only bold, but the icon is gone. This makes it difficult to see which is the current, I'm woking on.
Would be nice, if you fix that.

And, yes, I like SourceTree! :-)
Thanks
THomas
fields.summary: The active / current branch is not visible / no icon indicates the current branch

fields.description:
Source tree lacks the ability to arbitrarily diff between commits/stashes...
It's extremely useful.
fields.summary: Diff between a commit and a stash

fields.description: When using the Gitflow option, I want to finish my feature by rebasing the feature branch on the development branch, but instead it still performs a merge.
fields.summary: Gitflow rebase on feature finish still performs merge

fields.description: If Subtree require authentication, SourceTree does not prompt for password and fail to push/pull/clone the subtree.
fields.summary: Subtree does not work with HTTP(s) and SSH with passphrase

fields.description: Path is represented by %-ed Russian letters. It is too long, so window is partially hidden. I can not minimize this window.
fields.summary: Sizing with long repository path

fields.description:
Consider following setup:

# the repo on GitHub has 2 branches
# I clone the repo and now can see these 2 branches ("one" and "two") under "REMOTES > origin" in sidebar of SourceTree
# then on GitHub somebody removed branch "one" and adds branch "three"
# after doing fetch from "origin" remote the branch list is: "one", "two", "three" and not "two", "three"

This is because branches that are removed on remotes (if that removal was done outside of SourceTree) are not removed in SourceTree as well.

To fix this currently I need to do:

# rename "origin" to "origin2"
# rename "origin2" to "origin"
fields.summary: Remote branch list not refreshed after doing fetch

fields.description: I tried using SourceTree 2.0.2 to connect to a Stash server that has a project with ~500 repositories in it. However SourceTree only shows 25 repositories, no matter how much I refresh or try to scroll down. Perhaps an issue with the Stash REST paged APIs
fields.summary: Stash remote account only shows 25 repositories

fields.description:
Even with compact logos, the Repository Browser window still wastes a great deal of horizontal space.

When resizing the window smaller, I'd like the New Repository button to disappear and let me keep shrinking the window.  This would typically get rid of empty space in the window (see the attached before/after examples).

Thanks.
fields.summary: Allow "New Repository" button to be hidden

fields.description: Now the "External Diff" can only compare one file each time. Almost all the compare tools support folder compare. This is very useful when there is many changes in one commit.
fields.summary: Folder compare for "External Diff"

fields.description:
The add/link subtree dialog allows browsing for "Local Relative Path". 
Upon selecting a path, it is placed into the field with a full, absolute path (see below). 
e.g. /Users/david/Documents/Programming/pantheon/phw_pantheon/sites/all/modules/quiz

This causes the add/link to fail. Manually removing the leading part to leave only the relative path from the docroot allows the command to complete correctly (linking an existing subtree in my case). 
from example above:
sites/all/modules/quiz
works fine. 

I wonder if this also causes the initial Add to fail. 

Thanks!
fields.summary: Add/link subtree dialog should generate a relative path

fields.description:
We use git-flow on our repo and our repo has ref/HEAD configured to 'develop' so that novices don't accidentally commit to 'master' (see SRCTREE-2732 for more explanations).
On a local working copy that has been created/cloned with the command line git tool, the only existing local branch is 'develop'. Master is visible in the tree of remote branches. (this bug is not reproducible if the working copy has been created/cloned with SourceTree, see SRCTREE-2732).

If I try to initialize Git Flow in SourceTree, the operation is aborted with the following error message (also see attachment):"Cannot Create Production Branch
The production branch you chose, 'master', does not already exist. We can't create this automatically because the point in history where the production branch starts from is very important.
To resolve this, please create a new branch called 'master' at the point in your log which represents the current production state of your system, then come back and initialize again."

The operation sure enough proceeds correctly after double-clicking the remote branch 'master', but I believe this is a place where SourceTree could apply a little more "do what I mean".
fields.summary: SourceTree fails to initialize git-flow if local working copy is already on branch develop

fields.description:
When cloning a git repo with SourceTree, it always checks out the branch 'master' or whichever other I manually specify in 'Advanced Options', even if the ref/HEAD is configured to something else on the server. The command-line git however checks out the branch ref/HEAD is pointing to, e.g. 'develop'.

We work with git-flow in our git repository. To prevent novices from doing accidental commits in the master branch, we have configured ref/HEAD (on the server) to point to develop instead of master. This way, when freshly checked out, they sit in 'develop' instead of 'master' and can only do minor harm.

Unfortunately, SourceTree does not follow this rationale and always checks out 'master'. Even more unfortunately, there is no way for a git client to reliably recognize which workflow (like git-flow) is used on a repo, but that's totally different topic, just part of the motivation to change ref/HEAD to 'develop'.
fields.summary: SourceTree should check out ref/HEAD instead of branch master

fields.description: The bug was already reported in https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/SRCTREE-2637, but it is still not fixed even though the ticket says it was fixed in version 2.0.0. See attachment for the stack trace. Its recreated by just trying to switch a branch (in a hg repository window) by just double clicking on the branch name on the left slideout panel, in the "branches" section.
fields.summary: Crash when switching branch (still not fixed, 2.0.2)

fields.description:
The new icons in the Repository Browser (are they BitBucket branding?) are wasting valuable vertical resolution (now bloated to 50 pixels per row).

Yes, I do have a 4K monitor these days, but I shouldn't have to scroll this window to see all my projects when a row height of perhaps 24 pixels would do just fine.

While I'm griping about this, note that the new custom window header, while quite beautiful, also wastes a lot of vertical resolution.

These changes look quite out of place in the programmer's world of 9-point text. Also consider the context of Apple's ProApps like Final Cut or pretty much any pro tool like Maya where screen real estate is considered a premium.
fields.summary: Repo browser icons are superfluous

fields.description: We used to have a visual indicator of the currently selected branch, this was changed to be a bolded title in 2.0 and the indicator was removed. This should be brought back, it's very hard to tell at a glance which branch is checked out via bolding alone.
fields.summary: Very hard to see checked out branch using only bolding

fields.description:
After sparkle updates the Source Tree app the install files are not being removed from disk. With each version weighing in at 120-150mb this begins to add up. I would suggest doing a bit of cleanup by removing old versions from disk upon successful update.

~/Library/Application Support/SourceTree/.Sparkle
fields.summary: App needs to cleanup install files after sparkle update

fields.description:
SourceTree will hang if creating Bitbucket repository at {{Repository Settings >> Remotes >> Add >> URL/path (Globe button) >> Create New Repository}}

Actually, this old feature will be removed and replaced by the function "Publish to remote" in the Repository Browser
fields.summary: Creating repository in Bitbucket through Repository Setting will make SourceTree hang

fields.description: The visual indicators that show which branch is checked out under the Branches section are too subtle. If you're eyes aren't great it's hard to tell which branch is actually checked out. If the checked out branch is currently selected then it's impossible to tell if that is the checked out branch. I suggest that there be some additional visual indicator on the branch icon to show which branch is checked out.
fields.summary: Indication of which branch is checked out is too subtle

fields.description: "Commit merge immediately" checkbox state in "Merge fetched" window doesn't affect on behaviour. Merge doesn't commited automatically in both cases.
fields.summary: "Commit merge immediately" checkbox doesn't work

fields.description:
To reproduce:

1. Select a revision in branch view
2. Type something in the file name filter
3. Switch to working copy view, or distract yourself in any other way
4. Come back and click a revision which has no changes matching the filter from 2

Expected results:
It is very clear that the list of files is filtered, and that is why you do not see anything listed.

Actual results:
Even though this happens to me a couple times a week, it always takes me a second to figure out.

Suggestions:
I'm pretty sure that part of the reason I miss the filter is that it's way over on the right, next to the diff preview options. Moving it so that it's above the list it filters might help.
More useful, though, would be something like the "nothing to commit" message that appears when there are actually no changes in your working copy. I know it might seem hand-holdy, but a "clear search" button right under such a message (right in the middle of the empty list area!) would nearly eliminate the mental hang I get when results are filtered to nothing.
fields.summary: Empty filter results are inobvious

fields.description:
in sourcetree it would be helpful to have the option to choose to do a "blame" on a file using the "git -w" option which ignores whitespace.
as it is, any formatting changes cause the blame to be useless. ignoring whitespace on the other hand works great and shows the actual commit in which the commit was done.
fields.summary: add option to ignore whitespace in blame (-w)

fields.description:
When adding Custom Actions shortcut key, it will detect if the user input keys will conflict with the core shortcut key in SourceTree.

However, it detected "Stash Changes/Shelve" as CMD-S and let user insert CMD-SHIFT-S as the Custom Action shortcut key.

Actually, CMD-SHIFT-S is the shortcut key for "Stash Changes/Shelve" so the Custom Action with the shortcut key CMD-SHIFT-S will not work.

When adding Custom Actions shortcut key, SourceTree should detect CMD-SHIFT-S as "Stash Changes/Shelve" so that it will not let the user to insert CMD-SHIFT-S
fields.summary: When adding Custom Actions shortcut, it detect CMD-S as Stash Changes/Shelve

fields.description:
There isn't any Custom Actions when right click on the repository in the Bookmark window.

The Custom Actions only work with repository file.
fields.summary: Custom Actions not working in Bookmark Window

fields.description: options to do Repository Pull from Repository Browser window to single/All repositories.
fields.summary: Pull single or all repositories
UI mess in full screen mode

fields.description: OS X folder tag will be removed if SourceTree create repository with that folder by selecting the folder though a popup window
fields.summary: OS X folder tag cleared when creating repo

fields.description:
My company uses a number of small services, all residing in different git-repos, all of which I have full-screened in different spaces on the mac (5 or so).

Since the name of the repo isn't really anywhere to be seen unless you know what the different branches are, it would be tremendously helpful if the name of the repo could be added at the top of the left menu (above File Status, Branches and Tags etc.).

Terrific product gents, I am working on C# stuff and I have mac installed mainly so I can keep using source tree as a git client.
fields.summary: repo + branch-name when in full-screen

fields.summary: SourceTree crashes when trying to update from 1.9.7 to 2.0.1

fields.description:
Stashed some uncommitted changes successfully then STREE refreshed and crashed. 

See attached Console and Stack Trace logs.
fields.summary: Crash after stash

fields.description:
The shortcut to open a project from the bookmarks window is Command-Shift-O. Enter will instead enter a rename mode.

It would be much more appropriate if Enter instead was used for the least surprising action = Open Project. You seldom (or ever) rename a project.
With the current shortcut, pure keyboard navigation is a pain.
fields.summary: Let Enter mean "Open Project" in bookmark view

fields.description:
I just got a bit confused because it looked like there were no blobs in the graph for a bunch of commits.

It turns out (fairly obviously) that the graph column simply wasn't wide enough at that point.

I kind of think it should auto-size to fit the number of branches it's trying to show.

Alternatively, it would be good if there was a visual clue that there is more information that will fit in the current column width.

It's fairly trivial really, but it confused me and made me think that there was a bug.
fields.summary: Graph column should auto-size

fields.description:
The visual diff settings are disabled.

I have Kaleidoscope installed and reachable from the command line.

Not sure if this is a Yosemite thing, but it's been happening for a few versions of ST. I think I've also seen it on my laptop, which is 10.9.5, but I couldn't swear to it.
fields.summary: Visual Diff settings not available

fields.description: Crash in SourceTree. I can't honestly remember what I was doing...
fields.summary: Crash in NSTableView _dataCellForTableColumn:row:

fields.description:
When I launched SourceTree this morning, it asked me to install an update to version 2.0.0.  However, the "updated" app is giving me the following error when I launch it (see attached screenshot).

I was able to restore version 1.9.8 from the trash can and will continue using it until this issue is resolved.
fields.summary: SourceTree 2.0.1 "damaged or incomplete"

fields.description: After updating the application, when opening it again, the registration window pops up and I must again add my license file.
fields.summary: Registration removed after updating

fields.description:
Both GitHub and BitBucket allow users to comment on a commit. I don't mean the actual commit message, but in the web interface you can enter remarks on a commit and start an entire discussion.

It would be nice to populate the commit-tree with an icon that there are remarks on a commit. Clicking on it would go to the GitHub/BitBucket page to show the comments. Even better integration would be to view and even edit the comments from there.

BTW: Love your product. The only GIT client on Windows/OS X that makes using GIT a pleasure!
fields.summary: View and edit commit remarks (GitHub, BitBucket)

fields.description:
The updated Repository Browser window is very wide.  The last point release reduced it vertically by adding the compact view feature.  Thank you!  But I find the width of the window makes it very difficult to use.  I typically position the browser on the right side of my monitor.  In prior versions, the name of the repository was at least visible toward the right side of the view.  Now, there's a large amount of whitespace separating the repository name and the status elements due to the new elements in the header area (New Repository and filter field). 

I've attached a screenshot and highlighted the areas I'd like to see removed so the window can be compressed horizontally.
Thanks!
fields.summary: The Repository Browser is way too big

fields.description:
In the latest update to version 2.0.0 the icon which used to show which branch was the active branch has been removed.

-- Update: Tested in 2.0.1 and issue is still present.

Instead, the text is now just 'bold' for the active branch, which is not clear, especially when you have the active branch highlighted.

Please bring back the icon, or make it an option in preferences. This is severely impacting productivity, and causing commits and work done in the wrong branches for the whole team. Very urgent issue, which needs rectifying asap.
fields.summary: Active branch icon has been removed in latest update

fields.description:
When using the command-line utility *stree* and specifying a directory as parameter which isn't a repository yet, the SourceTree App only opens the dialog to create a new repository when the application is already running.

Example:
SourceTree App is already running.
Running {{stree ~/myfolder}} opens a dialog within the SourceTree App to create a new local repository.

Running the same command ({{stree ~/myfolder}}) while SourceTree isn't running just starts up the application *but omits the dialog*.

This was working with previous versions of the application. 

It works correctly with folders that already contain repositories, eg. {{stree ~/myExistingRepository}} opens the bookmark in SourceTree (or promts to create a new bookmark), no matter if the application was already running or not.
fields.summary: Launching via command-line doesn't open repository dialog

fields.description: I have a custom action that only uses the $REPO variable. I would expect it to be available under "Custom Actions" when right-clicking on a bookmark in the repository browser. However, it is grayed out in this context.
fields.summary: repository-level custom action should show up in context menu of repository browser

fields.description: Checked out branch used to be distinguished with special icon, now it just slightly different color of the same icon (and bold font). When u have long list of branches, it is not easy to see which one is active.
fields.summary: Currently checked out branch is not easily distinguishible

fields.description:
The Git commit textarea allows free form input. This is not helpful when writing git commit messages that can be easily read by other tools and on other platforms. For example, see Linus Torvalds' objection of using Github textarea for git commit messages 

http://programmers.stackexchange.com/questions/149199/why-do-some-open-source-projects-do-not-accept-pull-requests-but-emailing-patch

Proposal
=======
Git commit text area can be customised to:

1. Limit line length to 72/80
2. Show hint of line length
3. Hard wrapping of lines
fields.summary: Formatting of git commit message

fields.description:
Since upgrading to 2.0 I see a constant 80% CU usage by SourceTree. Closing windows will bring it down to 40% - 50%. 

Either w Yosemite Window Server issue or Sourcetree one.
fields.summary: Constant 80% CPU on Yosemite Public Beta 3

fields.description:
SourceTree for Mac has now a localization in Spanish for most of its UI. You went overboard, though, translating Git terminology such as "commit", "reset", "branch", "merge", "fetch", etc., in places like the toolbar (strangely not in some other places like menu commands), that are commonly used straight in English when speaking in (Spain’s at least) Spanish.

Everybody learns Git using the English terms and translating them into Spanish words that nobody uses nor relates to those commands makes the app more difficult to use, not easier.

Some few terms whose use in computer jargon do precede Git and other version control systems are, though, often translated, such as "parche" for "patch" (although even that is arguable).

Spanish users surely appreciate having the UI in Spanish, just not Git commands. Please, have those translations reviewed by Spanish users that are actual Git and SourceTree active users, and in case of doubt, lean towards leaving the English version intact.
fields.summary: App should not localize Git terminology to Spanish

fields.description:
It could be nice to have an option to disable sub-folder scanning

The results should have latest commit info too.
fields.summary: Ability to disable subfolder scanning for Scan a Directory function

fields.description: Shortcut key for custom actions do not work in SourceTree 2.0.0
fields.summary: Shortcut Key for Custom Actions do not work

fields.description:
How to reproduce:

# open SourceTree
# drag main SourceTree window (that has bookmarks) to any position
# close the app completely
# open app

Note that window always opens in same position and not at place where it was closed.

There was no such problem with 1.x versions of SourceTree
fields.summary: Window position isn't retained after restart

fields.description: The translation of "rebase", "变基", has another meaning in Chinese: become a gay... Would you please find a better translation...
fields.summary: An ambiguous translation

fields.description:
If "Offer to create bookmarks for newly created repositories" is enabled in SourceTree's preferences, then the "Create Bookmarks?" window appears when a repo is opened for the first time in SourceTree.

If the "Create Bookmarks?" window is closed using ⌘W or the close button in its titlebar, then the UI gets put in a useless state.  All menu options either become grayed out or don't do anything, any open windows can't be interacted with or closed, and SourceTree can't be quit via ⌘Q or the menu option.

If the "Create Bookmarks?" window is closed via the "Cancel" button, then this bug is not triggered.

*Steps to reproduce:*

1. In a Terminal window, run:

{code}
mkdir /tmp/foo
cd /tmp/foo
git init
open -a SourceTree .
{code}

2. When the "Create Bookmarks?" window appears, close it with ⌘W or the close button in the titlebar.

3. SourceTree's UI is now in a useless state.

*Idle conjecture:*

It looks like the "Create Bookmarks?" window is trying to be made application-modal in a non-standard way, and closing the window instead of using the "Cancel" button doesn't run whatever code resets the rest of the UI back to the pre-sorta-modal state.
fields.summary: Closing "Create Bookmarks?" window puts UI in useless state

fields.description: Take a look at the screenshot.
fields.summary: Pixelated "number of changes" and bitbucket icon in bookmark window
